title: 107_s1350
content: The Act titled "Medicare Ambulance Payment Reform Act of 2001" establishes new payment rates for ambulance services. The Medicare Ambulance Payment Reform Act of 2001 establishes new payment rates for ground ambulance services in 2002 under the fee schedule. The Medicare Ambulance Payment Reform Act of 2001 sets new payment rates for ground ambulance services in 2002 based on average costs incurred by full-cost ambulance suppliers for nonemergency basic life support services. Adjustments for other ground ambulance service levels will be determined according to established rules. The Medicare Ambulance Payment Reform Act of 2001 establishes payment rates for ground ambulance services in 2002 based on costs incurred by full-cost ambulance suppliers. The Secretary will set payment rates for other ambulance services not covered by this provision under the fee schedule. The Medicare Ambulance Payment Reform Act of 2001 sets payment rates for ground ambulance services in 2002 based on costs incurred by full-cost suppliers. For ambulance services in 2003 and beyond, payment rates will be set at the previous year's rate plus the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index. The Medicare Ambulance Payment Reform Act of 2001 establishes payment rates for ground ambulance services based on costs incurred by full-cost suppliers. Starting in 2003, rates will be adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index. Additionally, for ambulance services in low-density rural areas, fee schedule payment rates will be adjusted to account for the increased cost of providing services in those areas. The Medicare Ambulance Payment Reform Act of 2001 sets payment rates for ground ambulance services based on costs incurred by full-cost suppliers. Rates will be adjusted annually starting in 2003, with additional adjustments for services in low-density rural areas. Section 221(c) of the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 is repealed, and a technical amendment redesignates a paragraph in the Social Security Act. The enactment of section 221(a) involves amending the coding system for ambulance services under the Social Security Act to specify the medical condition of the individual being transported. The coding system for ambulance services under the Social Security Act will be amended to specify the medical condition of the individual being transported, taking into account a list of medical conditions developed through a negotiated rulemaking process and adopted as a standard code set under section 1173(c). SEC. 3. PRUDENT LAYPERSON STANDARD FOR EMERGENCY AMBULANCE SERVICES UNDER MEDICARE AND MEDICAID. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding ambulance services for Medicare Fee-For-Service beneficiaries and Medicare+Choice Enrollees to ensure that ambulance services are considered necessary if requested after a sudden onset of a medical emergency condition. Amendments to the Social Security Act include adding ambulance services in Medicaid Managed Care Plans, with the changes applying to services provided after the enactment of the Act.
